summary: classical swine fever virus (CSFV) is a small, enveloped, positive-sense, and single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae (1). there is an urgent need for the development of alternative control strategies, such as marker vaccines (2, 3). studies have suggested that C-strain CSFV is a potent inducer of type I T-cell responses. NK cells are triggered to kill or ignore transformed or pathogen-infected cells, depending on a balance of inhibitory and activating signals received through ligands on potential target cells. some pathogens can directly activate NK cells, such as influenza virus activation of human NK cells through hemagglutinin-NKp46 receptor binding (11) or murine cytomegalovirus-activating NK cells via the m157 glycoprotein-Ly49 receptor interaction (12), the a third NK cell population with a CD8/low NKp46high phenotype has been described in porcine spleens. studies of the role of porcine NK cells in the response to viral infection are limited, but there are data showing that porcine NK cell responses are impaired following infection with foot-and-mouth disease virus. the activation of T cells can be direct or indirect, mediated by the interaction with APCs, such as DCs. in humans and pigs, it has been shown that T cells can express CD8 and MHC-II molecules. in swine, T cells can express both CD8 and MHC-II molecules. an ex vivo analysis of NK and T cells in the tonsils and retropharyngeal lymph nodes from pigs vaccinated with virulent CSFV. a live attenuated C-strain CSFV and the virulent CSFV Brescia strain were propagated in PK15 cell monolayers. large white/Landrace crossbreed pigs, 6 to 24 months of age, were randomly assigned to one of four groups. five days prior to challenge, the animals in groups 1 (n = 6) and 3 (n = 12) were vaccinated intranasally with 105 the 50% tissue culture infective dose (TCID50) of C-strain CSFV (1 ml divided equally between each nostril and administered using a mucosal atomization device. a total clinical score for each animal was assigned twice daily. temperatures were monitored by rectal thermometer readings and recorded once daily. each animal was stunned and euthanized by exsanguination. cells were washed twice in HBSS and resuspended in RPMI 1640 medium. cells were adjusted to a density of 1 107 to 2 107 cells/ml in cold 10% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) in FBS and cryopreserved as described earlier. CSFV RNA was quantified by qRT-PCR as described previously (34) and normalized to 18S RNA using the Eukaryotic 18S rRNA endogenous control. samples from the tonsils were collected, fixed in Bouin's solution, and embedded in paraffin wax. sections were dewaxed, rehydrated, and then treated in hydrogen peroxide 3% in methanol for 15 min to eliminate endogenous peroxidase activity. normal goat serum (1:66 dilution) and normal pig serum (1:33 dilution) were added before being washed twice in TBST. the sections were incubated for 30 min at room temperature with avidin-biotin complex (ABC Vector Elite; Vector Laboratories, Peterborough, United Kingdom) a titration of recombinant porcine IFN- (R&D Systems) was added as a standard. PBMC were resuspended in CD14 microbeads (10 l/107 cells; Miltenyi Biotec) and incubated at room temperature (RT) for 10 min. cells were stained with anti-CD4-PerCP-Cy5.5 MAb (clone 8E6, 2 g/107 cells; WSUMAC), CD8 (clone PT36B, 2 g/107 cells; WSUMAC), and CD21 (clone X56, 1 g/107 cells; BD Biosciences) for sorting, the cells were washed, resuspended at a density of 107 cells/ml in cRP mDCs and pDCs were shown to be >90% pure after flow cytometry sorting. aliquot of PBMC stained with an MAb against 1 g/107 cells -TcR1-N4 (clone PGBL22A; WSUMAC), followed by mouse IgG microbeads and a collection of the positive fraction following separation on an LS column. clone BB238E68C8 showed a purity of the NK cells that ranged from 70 to 80%. the cells were cultured in the presence of recombinant porcine cytokines IL-12 (100 ng/ml), IL-18 (100 ng/ml), IFN- (4,000, 2,000, or 1,000 U/ml), and/or TNF- (800, 400, or 200 pg/ml) culture supernatants from mock- and CSFV-infected sorted mDC and pDC populations were incubated for 24 to 48 h at 37°C in a 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere. the cells were resuspended, centrifuged for 2 min, and the supernatants were stored at 80°C until analyzed. cells were thawed in a 37°C water bath and washed in prewarmed cRPMI. cell densities were determined as described above, adjusted to 1 107 cells/ml, and 100 l was transferred to the wells of a 96-well round-bottom plate. the cells were stained with the MAbs specific for surface markers for 10 min at RT. unconjugated CD3 and TcR1-N4 MAbs were labeled using the Zenon Alexa Fluor 647 and Alexa Fluor 405 mouse IgG1 labeling kits. surface-stained cells were fixed using CellFIX (BD Biosciences) for 10 min at RT and then analyzed or were fixed and permeabilized using CytoFix/CytoPerm solution (BD Biosciences) after two washes in BD Perm/W FITC-IgG2b isotype control (27-35; BD Biosciences), and unconjugated IgG1 isotype control (AbD Serotec), respectively. all the washes used centrifugation at 930 g for 2 min. the cells were analyzed on MACSQuant Analyzer (Miltenyi Biotec) or CyAn ADP (Beckman Coulter) flow cytometers. animals were vaccinated intranasally with 105 the 50% tissue culture infective dose (TCID50) of C-strain CSFV (1 ml divided equally between each nostril and administered using a mucosal atomization device [MAD-300] group 4 (n = 12) was inoculated with 1 ml of mock virus supernatant. on days 2 and 0, three animals were euthanized from groups 2 to 4. on days 3 and 5, three animals were euthanized from all four groups. a total clinical score for each animal was assigned twice daily. cells were washed twice in HBSS and resuspended in RPMI 1640 medium. cells were adjusted to a density of 1 107 to 2 107 cells/ml in cold 10% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) in FBS. 200 mg of tissue was homogenized in 4 ml RLT buffer. tissue homogenates were clarified by centrifugation for 10 min at 1,000 g. RNA was extracted using the RNeasy maxi kit with the additional DNase treatment. a mouse MAb against porcine IFN- (clone F17; R&D Systems) was added at 1.82 g/ml. sections were incubated for 30 min with a 1:100 dilution of biotinylated secondary antibody. negative-control sections were included in each run. blood was collected in serum separator tubes at 1,500 g for 10 min. serum was obtained by centrifugation at 1,500 g for 10 min and stored at 80°C until analyzed. cells were resuspended in PBS supplemented with 2% FBS and 5 mM EDTA (MACS buffer, 1 ml/2.5 108 cells) the cells were stained with an MAb against CD172a (clone 74-22-15A, 1 g MAb/107 cells; washman, WA, USA) the cells were then washed and incubated with mouse IgG microbeads (10 l/107 cells; Miltenyi Bio the cells were washed, resuspended at a density of 107 cells/ml in cRPMI. lineage CD4 mDCs and lineage CD4+ pDCs were sorted using a moFlo Astrios cell sorter. the purity of the enriched and sorted DC populations was assessed by flow cytometry. cells by indirect staining with an MAb against CD3 (clone 8E6, 1 g/107 cells; WSUMAC), followed by staining with mouse IgG microbeads, collection of the flowthrough, and washes on an LD column. purity was assessed after staining an aliquot with an MAb against CD8-phycoerythrin (PE) and CD3-APC (clone BB238E68C8; the cells were cultured in the presence of recombinant porcine cytokines IL-12 (100 ng/ml), IL-18 (100 ng/ml), IFN- (4,000, 2,000, or 1,000 U/ml) and/or TNF- (800, 400, or 200 pg/ml) the cultures were incubated for 24 to 48 h in a 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere. dilutions of culture supernatants to reporter bovine kidney cells (MDBK-t2) for 24 h and an assessment of CAT expression by ELISA. cytofluorometric analysis of NK and T cells from the in vitro experiments was performed directly. surface-stained cells were fixed using CellFIX (BD Biosciences) for 10 min at RT and then washed twice with FACS buffer. the cells were incubated with MAbs at RT for 10 min in the dark. the cells were given two final washes in BD Perm/Wash buffer and resuspended in FACS buffer prior to flow cytometric analysis. the cells were analyzed by gating on viable cells (LIVE/DEAD fixable dead cell stain negative) in the lymphocyte population. the defined lymphocyte subpopulations were then gated upon and their expression of MHC-II, perforin, and CSFV-E2 assessed. the direct effects of a live attenuated C-strain and the virulent Brescia strain of CSFV were assessed on NK and T cells in vitro. the direct effects of a live attenuated C-strain and the virulent Brescia strain of CSFV were assessed on NK and T cells. a mock virus-infected cryolysate supernatant and a cocktail of recombinant porcine IL-12 and IL-18 were used as negative and positive controls. the percentages of MHC-II- and perforin-expressing cells were assessed on the NK cells (A) and T cells (B) by flow cytometry. enriched NK and T cells were cocultured with attenuated C-strain or virulent Brescia strain CSFV or with culture supernatants from enriched blood DCs previously infected with the two strains. a mock virus-infected cryolysate supernatant was used as a negative control. no significant differences were observed in the levels of IL-1, IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-8, IL-10 NK and T cells were cultured with recombinant porcine IFN- and TNF-. the effects on MHC-II expression were assessed. pDCs or mDCs were exposed to a mock virus-infected cryolysate supernatant. pDC cocultures and the expression of MHC-II were assessed by flow cytometry after 24 h. the values for each group were compared to the unstimulated control. experiments were performed in the context of CSFV vaccination and/or challenge. some evidence of an upregulation of MHC-II on NK and T cells in the draining lymph nodes from intranasally vaccinated animals. at this time, there was a significantly greater proportion of MHC-II expressing NK and T cells in both the tonsils and retropharyngeal lymph nodes of the challenge control pigs compared to those that were vaccinated but unchallenged. the data represent the mean of 3 pigs/group/time point SEM. the tonsils and retropharyngeal lymph nodes were collected longitudinally following C-strain vaccination and/or virulent Brescia challenge. the data represent the mean of 3 pigs/group SEM. the data represent the mean of 3 pigs/group SEM. a one-way ANOVA followed by Bonferroni's multiple comparison test. a mock virus-infected supernatant and a cocktail of recombinant porcine IL-12 and IL-18 were used as negative and positive controls. the percentages of MHC-II- and perforin-expressing cells were assessed on the NK cells (A) and T cells (B) by flow cytometry. enriched NK and T cells were cocultured with attenuated C-strain or virulent Brescia strain CSFV or with culture supernatants from enriched blood DCs previously infected with the two strains (A) a mock virus-infected cryolysate supernatant was used as a negative control. the values for each virus-stimulated condition were compared to the corresponding mock-stimulated control. IL-6, IL-8, IL-10, IL-12, or IFN- were detected in the supernatants of virus-infected pDC cultures. significantly higher levels of type I IFN and TNF- were detected in the supernatants of virus-infected pDC cultures compared to those of mDCs. the effects on MHC-II expression were assessed. ex vivo analysis of NK and T cells isolated from the tonsils and retropharyngeal lymph nodes of pigs vaccinated and/or challenged with CSFV. pigs developed clinical signs of CSF, viremia, and leukopenia (33) on day 0 postchallenge, there was some evidence of an upregulation of MHC-II on T cells in the draining lymph nodes from intranasally vaccinated animals. at this time point, there was a significantly greater proportion of MHC-II expressing NK and T cells in both the tonsils and retropharyngeal lymph nodes of the challenge control pigs compared to those that were vaccinated but unchallenged. the data represent the mean of 3 pigs/group/time point SEM. the tonsils and retropharyngeal lymph nodes were collected longitudinally following C-strain vaccination. pDCs infected with CSFV released significantly smaller amounts of IFN- compared to pDCs. pDCs possess a functional type I IFN response to CSFV infection. IFN- is the prototypic antiviral cytokine, but also plays an important immunoregulatory role, enhancing both innate and adaptive immune responses. we report this effect on two nonconventional APCs, NK and T cells, in pigs. this may be explained by the more limited replication of C-strain in vivo. it is possible that some form of immune regulation is induced by C-strain infection, such as IL-10 induction, which may inhibit the pDC-mediated type I IFN response. pDCs can rapidly replicate in macrophages and mDCs. the ability of NK cells to express MHC-II after interaction with DCs has been described in mice. recombinant cytokines and supernatants derived from pDC cultures induced the upregulation of MHC-II on NK cells. viral cytokines, like IFN-, or perforin-mediated cytotoxic function, raise the possibility that CSFV actively inhibits this process. studies of HCV, another member of the Flaviviridae family, have shown that several viral proteins can either directly or indirectly, in the case of NS5A, inhibit human NK cell activation. data failed to show that these cells gained antiviral effector functions. it therefore appears unlikely that either population contribute directly to the rapid protection conferred by C-strain CSFV.
